text: Private Bill Committees are set up to deal with the legislation required for major public sector infrastructure projects — such as the underground extensions to the National Gallery of Scotland in 2003. The Scottish Parliament has a number of committees, with small numbers of Members appointed to scrutinise the work of the Scottish Government. Much of the work of the Scottish Parliament is done in committee. The role of committees is stronger in the Scottish Parliament than in other parliamentary systems, partly as a means of strengthening the role of backbenchers in their scrutiny of the GovernmentDardanelli (2005) p185 and partly to compensate for the fact that the parliament is unicameral (there is no revising chamber). The principal role of committees in the Scottish Parliament is to conduct inquiries, scrutinise legislation and hold the government to account. Committee meetings take place in the Parliament's committee rooms all day Tuesday and Wednesday morning when Parliament is sitting. Committees can also meet at other locations throughout Scotland. Membership of the committees reflects the balance of parties across Parliament. There are different types of committee, with their functions set out in different ways. The membership of the committees is shown below. All committees also have substitute members (not shown). ==Mandatory Committees== Mandatory Committees are committees which are set down under the Scottish Parliament's standing orders, which govern their remits and proceedings. The current Mandatory Committees of the Scottish Parliament are: ===Culture, Tourism, Europe and External Relations=== {| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0 0 0 1em; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaaaaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; " ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Liam Kerr||Scottish Conservative Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Monica Lennon||Scottish Labour Party |- |} ===Public Petitions=== The remit of the Committee is to decide what action should be taken on admissible public petitions. The committee is also responsible for deciding, in cases of dispute, whether a public petition is admissible. On 16 June 2009 the Committee reported on its 'Inquiry into the public petitions process'Inquiry into the public petitions process Scottish Parliament Paper 300, 3rd Report, 2009 (Session 3) (PU/S3/09/R3) (Accessed 16.06.2009) issued to reflect 10 years of operation, which included an evaluation of the pioneering e-Petitioner online petitioning system. {| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0 0 0 1em; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaaaaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; " ! Typically each committee corresponds with one (or more) of the departments (or ministries) of the Scottish Government. style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Ruth Maguire||Scottish National Party |- |} ==Conveners' Group== The Conveners' Group is a special committee of the Scottish Parliament chaired by either the Presiding Officer of the Scottish Parliament or one of the Deputy Presiding Officers. Its main responsibilities are involved in the administration of Committee expenses and certain other activities. {| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0 0 0 1em; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaaaaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; " ! colspan="2"|Name || Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Christine Grahame (Chair and Deputy Presiding Officer)||Scottish National Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Clare Adamson||Scottish National Party |- ! style="background- color: ; width: 1px" | |Bruce Crawford||Scottish National Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Graeme Dey||Scottish National Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Bob Doris||Scottish National Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |James Dornan||Scottish National Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Neil Findlay||Scottish Labour Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Johann Lamont||Scottish Labour Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Gordon Lindhurst||Scottish Conservative Party |- ! style="background- color: ; width: 1px" | |Joan McAlpine||Scottish National Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Christina McKelvie||Scottish National Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Jenny Marra||Scottish Labour Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Margaret Mitchell||Scottish Conservative Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Edward Mountain||Scottish Conservative Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |John Scott||Scottish Conservative Party |- ! style="background-color: ; width: 1px" | |Sandra White||Scottish National Party |} ==Previous Committees== ===Private Bill Committees=== A further type of committee is normally set up to scrutinise private bills submitted to the Scottish Parliament by an outside party or promoter who is not a member of the Scottish Parliament or Scottish Government. Private bills normally relate to large-scale development projects such as infrastructure projects that require the use of land or property. Private Bill Committees have been set up to consider legislation on issues such as the development of the Edinburgh Tram Network, the Glasgow Airport Rail Link, the Airdrie- Bathgate Rail Link and extensions to the National Gallery of Scotland.
